slide.title: Frameworks
slide.p: An MVC framework is one with conventions and pre-built components that encourage or enforce good programming practices.
CodeIgniter is one such framework.

div.p: It is an "industry-accepted best practice", that says that it is good to keep separate concerns apart from each other.
CodeIgniter has base classes for models and controllers, and it has components to build presentation content separate from these. This is not conventional PHP scripting!

A typical MVC framework incorporates many other
design patterns:

slide.title: Categorizing MVC Frameworks
slide.p: Frameworks come in all sizes.
They differ in philosophy, scope, management tools & included plugins.

tr.td: Scaffolding, auth, ORM, CLI, IDE plugin
Engines (templating, ORM), included plugins, installer, starter, generators

div.p: A CodeIgniter project contains application logic and support files.
"index.php", in the document root, *is* the front controller, i.e. entry point.
".htaccess" is an Aoache configuration file, to eliminate the need to explicitly have "index.php" in URLs.

slide.title: Folder Structures
slide.p: Other frameworks follow similar conventions.

slide.title: Class Loader
slide.p: CodeIgniter has its own class loader.
It uses the folder structure to locate classes (per MVC)
It enforces naming conventions too.

slide.title: Routing
slide.p: CodeIgniter normally routes requests to controllers by convention, i.e. using the URI segment and looking in the controllers folder.
Other frameworks often handle routing a bit differently.

div.p: Models encapsulate data sources or entities.
Each model is a class that wraps a data source.
CodeIgniter encourages the Active Record design patterm which says you build CRUD methods into models.
CodeIgniter comes with a QueryBuilder library, to make it easier to access your databases.
In CodeIgniter, models are classes that extend CI_Model.
Each data source, eg. RDB table, has its own model.

slide.title: Model Methods
slide.p: CRUD
Some business logic
Work with objects or associative arrays
* not * beans, i.e. entity models
Do not generate views, but generate or provide data to be passed to views
Usage: $this->load->model('goodies');

slide.title: Base Model
slide.p: You can provide your own base model, MY_Model, with common methods.
This could be used to provide a simple object-relational map.
Sample properties: $_tableName, $_keyField
Sample methods: create() get($key), add($record), update($record), delete($key), exists($key)

slide.title: Other Model Examples
slide.p: Other frameworks have similar functionality.

div.p: A Controller serves as an intermediary between the Model, the View, and any other resources needed to process an HTTP request and generate a web page.
In CI, controllers are classes that extend CI_Controller or your base controller
Our base controller implements view templating, through render()

slide.title: App Controllers
slide.p: Each of your webapp controllers builds on your base controller
Normally, each usecase has its own controller
Additionally, controllers or subcontrollers are used for services
See application/controllers/welcome.php

slide.title: Controller Methods
slide.p: URLs are segment based
example.com/class/function/parm1/parm2
index() is the default handler function
Other functions are treated as sub-controllers
Parameters are passed positionally
Confusion is possible ... Application/controllers/business/work

slide.title: Example Base Controller
slide.p: core/MY_Controller.php

slide.title: Views
slide.p: Views are the components that deal with presentation, typically for a web browser.

slide.title: Support Components
slide.p: An MVC framework comes with a number of pre-built classes or scripts to make your webapp development easier and more consistent.
These are collectively referred to as support components

slide.p: This is a simplified look at where stuff goes inside your webapp, and the general steps you would follow to build a simple CodeIgniter webapp.
